key_points: The author, a union prop master with over 20 years of experience, reflects on the 'Rust' shooting incident.
Cinematographer Halyna Hutchins was killed and director Joel Souza injured on the set of 'Rust' due to alleged lack of diligence.
The author compares rigorous safety protocols and team cohesion from their experience on 'Saturday Night Live' to the purported conditions on 'Rust'.
Media reports and inside accounts suggest that 'Rust' suffered from long days, insufficient accommodations, and low morale.
Assistant Director David Halls, who handed Alec Baldwin the fatal gun, admitted to not checking all the rounds, according to a search warrant affidavit.
Halls had a history of disregarding safety protocols, and there were two previous accidental discharges on the 'Rust' set.
Hannah Gutierrez, the armorer on 'Rust', was relatively inexperienced, having only one other stint as head armorer.
The article highlights the importance of admitting ignorance and seeking help, especially concerning firearm safety, in the prop master's profession.
Patience, fairness, and adherence to safety protocols are emphasized as crucial to successful and safe film production.
The 'Rust' tragedy is presented as an ironic and cautionary tale, urging the film industry to respect worker safety to prevent fatal accidents.
